Chapter 5, Part 4: The Chapter on the Bodhisattva of Oceanic Wisdom
At that time, the Bodhisattva of Oceanic Wisdom addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are endowed with such views, what kind of vows do they give rise to?
The Buddha said:
Good man!

Such people give rise to vows as they originally did. If the mind of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas is in samÄdhi or not in samÄdhi, for the sake of sentient beings they give rise to vows as they originally did.
Good man!

It is like a person who has a sugar cane and rice field full of one cheng. The land is level and even. When wanting to irrigate, they open the water gate and let it go. Without further effort, it naturally spreads everywhere.
Good man!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. If they are in concentration, they fix their thoughts and contemplate, but if they are not in concentration and not contemplating, for the sake of sentient beings they make vows as before, and all the wholesome roots they wish to share with sentient beings. Having shared them, they dedicate them to the unsurpassed Buddha Dharma.
The bodhisattva's mind is pure, and his precepts, patience, concentration, and wisdom are also pure. He observes that the Buddha Dharma and all sentient beings are equal and non-dual.

Although he has this vow, he has no mind at all. Therefore, although the bodhisattva has no mind, by the power of his vows he never fails to reach all sentient beings. He shares all his wholesome roots with them, and having shared them, he dedicates them to unsurpassed enlightenment.
Good man!
It is like a Å›Äla tree. If someone cuts it down, once the roots are severed, it falls wherever it is cut.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. They cultivate samÄdhi and always turn towards enlightenment.
Suppose someone were to proclaim:
'This tree should not be cut down.'
But the tree still fell wherever it was cut.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. If the wholesome dharmas they cultivate are not directed towards unsurpassed bodhi, it is impossible.
Why is this?
Because the nature of dharmas is so.

The wholesome dharmas cultivated by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are only for the sake of not severing the lineage of the Three Jewels, for the sake of purifying the buddha-land, for the sake of adorning the body with the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks, for the sake of adorning the mouth so that when teaching the Dharma beings will enjoy listening, for the sake of adorning the mind in contemplating all beings equally without duality, and for the sake of attaining the buddha-dharmas and the samÄdhis of all buddhas.
Although bodhisattvas do not crave such dharmas, they are able to attain such dharmas freely.
Why is this?
Because of the power of their vows.
Good man!
It is like a potter. When the clay is on the wheel, it is not called a vessel. Only after it has been formed into a vessel can a name be given to it according to the vessel.
The good dharmas of the bodhisattva are also like this. Before making a vow, they cannot obtain the name of pÄramitÄ. Therefore, the bodhisattva's all good dharmas must make a vow.
Good son!
It is like a goldsmith who has not yet made an implement out of gold, and also does not obtain a name. When it is made, it obtains the name of an ornament.
The good dharmas of the bodhisattva are also like this. Before making a vow, they cannot obtain the name of pÄramitÄ.
Good son!
It is like a bhiká¹£u who wishes to enter the samÄdhi of cessation first makes a vow, saying:
'I will now enter samÄdhi.
If the ghaá¹‡á¹­Ä sounds, I will then arise and emerge.'
But within this samÄdhi there is no sound of the ghaá¹‡á¹­Ä. Due to the power of the vow, when the ghaá¹‡á¹­Ä sounds, he immediately arises from samÄdhi.
Good son!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is also like this. Out of compassion for sentient beings, he makes such a vow, saying:
'Those who have not yet crossed over, I will cause them to cross over. Those who have not yet been liberated, I will cause them to be liberated.'

When cultivating bodhi, they enter deep samÄdhi, and due to the power of compassion, they think of all sentient beings, not realizing the vehicle of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas. Therefore, although bodhisattvas cultivate the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, they do not attain the fruits.
Good man!
The practices of bodhisattvas are inconceivable. Although they enter deep samÄdhi, they do not realize the fruits of the path of Å›ramaá¹‡as.
Good man!
It is like two people trying to cross a raging fire. One person wears adamantine armor and can cross it, while the other's body is wrapped in dry grass and is burned by the fire.
Why is it so?
Because grass is easily burned, while gold is hard.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. They have compassion for sentient beings and single-mindedly think of bodhi. They adorn themselves with the extremely deep and immeasurable samÄdhi. By the power of samÄdhi, they can surpass the correct positions of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas without realizing the fruits. After rising from samÄdhi, they attain the path of right enlightenment and the samÄdhi of the TathÄgata.

Those covered with dry grass are likened to the Å›rÄvakas. The Å›rÄvakas are weary of and regretful about saá¹ƒsÄra, and have no compassionate mind towards sentient beings. Therefore, they are unable to surpass the correct stage of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
Why is it so?
The two vehicles have a sense of contentment towards merit and virtue, but the bodhisattvas have no sense of weariness towards merit and virtue.

The adamantine armor is likened to emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, and the great raging fire is likened to conditioned phenomena. The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate all phenomena as empty, signless, and wishless, yet are able to not realize the fruit of the path of the Å›ramaá¹‡as.
World-Honored One!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are endowed with these inconceivable things. They cultivate this samÄdhi but do not realize it. They enter the fire of saá¹ƒsÄra but are not burned. The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas accomplish skillful means and enter all samÄdhis, yet are not deceived by the samÄdhis. It is because they are endowed with skillful means.

Although they engage in various practices, their minds are unstained and attached. Although they speak of the fruits of asceticism for those with wrong views, they themselves do not realize the fruits of the path of ascetics.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
It is truly as you have said.
Good man!
It is like three dyed juices placed in one vessel, namely lac, saffron, and blue-green dye, dyeing three kinds of things, namely wool, cotton, and silk.
Wool soaked in water becomes blue, cotton washed clean becomes yellow, and silk soaked in ash becomes red. Although the three things are in the same vessel, they receive different colors.
Good man!
The people of the Three Vehicles are also like this.
The vessel is a metaphor for emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness;ğŸ”½The three kinds of colors are metaphors for the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas;
Following the clothes receiving the colors is a metaphor for the three kinds of enlightenment.
They also do not give rise to thoughts of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, thinking, 'This is the fruit, that is not the fruit.'
Good sons!
Cotton is a metaphor for Å›rÄvakas, cloth is a metaphor for pratyekabuddhas, and silk is a metaphor for the bodhisattva vehicle.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas see all dharmas as deaf and blind, without sentient beings. When they see in this way, their minds are unstained and unattached, without regret or retreat.
At that time, in their minds they truly understand:
I am neither a benefit to sentient beings nor not a benefit to sentient beings, and I also cultivate great compassion for sentient beings.
Good sons!
It is like a subtle and pure lapis lazuli jewel. Even if it is in mud for a hundred years, its nature is always pure, and when taken out it is as it was originally.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. They understand that the nature of the mind is originally pure, obstructed and defiled by adventitious dust and afflictions, and yet the adventitious afflictions truly cannot defile the pure mind, just as the jewel in the mud is not defiled by the mud.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas think like this:
'If the nature of my mind is defiled by afflictions, how can I transform sentient beings?'

Therefore, bodhisattvas always delight in cultivating the adornments of blessings and virtues, delight in making offerings to the Three Jewels in the various existences, and delight in serving and attending to sentient beings.

In places of greed, they do not give rise to greedy minds. They uphold the true Dharma, delight in practicing generosity, perfect the precepts, adorn themselves with patience, diligently practice vigor, adorn themselves with the branches of meditation, cultivate wisdom, are insatiable in their learning, and cultivate pure brahmacarya, great spiritual powers, and the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
Good man!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who practice such dharmas are not defiled by afflictions, are not attached to the three realms. Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice skillful means and the power of merit and virtue, and although they practice in the three realms, their body and mind are not defiled.
Good man!
It is like an elder who has only one child, cherishing him deeply in his heart. The child, while playing, mistakenly falls into a latrine.

When the mother sees this, she is disgusted by the filth and impurity. The father, seeing this later, scolds the mother, and then enters the latrine to pull the child out. After pulling the child out, he cleans it. Because of love, he forgets the stench and filth.
Good man!

The elder's parents are likened to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas. The latrine is likened to the three realms. The child is likened to sentient beings. The mother's inability to pull out the child is likened to the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas. The father's ability to rescue is likened to the bodhisattvas. The cause of love is likened to great compassion.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, possessing skillful means, enter the three realms, but are not defiled by the three realms.
Therefore, there are two kinds of paths:
First, the Å›rÄvakas;
Second, the bodhisattvas.
The Å›rÄvakas' path is to be disgusted with the three realms. The bodhisattvas' path is not to be disgusted with the three realms.
Good man!

Bodhisattvas cultivate emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness. Although they practice existence, they do not fall into existence. Since they do not fall into existence, they do not attain realization. Practicing in the three realms is called skillful means. Not attaining realization is called wisdom.
Good man!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate all dharmas as having no two characteristics. If they contemplate the equality of dharmas, sentient beings are also equal. Such equality is also the equality of nirvÄá¹‡a. This is called wisdom.
If one is able to contemplate sentient beings as equal in this way without realizing nirvÄá¹‡a, this is called skillful means.
Pure and clean giving is called wisdom. Making vows and dedicating merit is called skillful means.
World-Honored One!
What is called pure wisdom and pure skillful means?
Good man!
If bodhisattvas see that sentient beings, life, and personhood are selfless, this is called wisdom.
If one cultivates emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, and with all wholesome roots, vows and sentient beings, dedicates them to enlightenment, this is called skillful means.
Furthermore, good man!
Knowing the superior, middling, and inferior faculties of all sentient beings is called wisdom.
Knowing and then speaking the Dharma according to one's intention is called skillful means.

Because of pure wisdom, although one practices in various existences, the mind is without defilement. Because of pure skillful means, although one cultivates the two vehicles, one does not realize their fruits.
Good man!
If one is not defiled by any afflictions, this is called wisdom.
Being able to tame sentient beings and cause them all to head towards supreme, perfect enlightenment is called skillful means.

Bodhisattvas make vows to cause all sentient beings to obtain inexhaustible wealth, inexhaustible blessings and virtues, and increase their wholesome roots. For all learners, non-learners, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all bodhisattvas, being able to obtain the Dharma according to one's intention is called pure skillful means.

If one is able to uphold all the Buddha's teachings, to explain them extensively, to explain them without end, to explain them without obstruction, to explain them without fail, and to explain them according to one's wishes, this is called pure wisdom.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, wherever they are born, do not lose the mind of unsurpassed enlightenment. This is called pure wisdom.
Wherever they are born, they vow to do good for themselves and others. This is called pure skillful means.

Because of the causes and conditions of pure wisdom, they know that the mind of enlightenment is without abode and without basis. Because of pure skillful means, they transform all sentient beings and lead them to enlightenment.
World-Honored One!
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas possess these two purities, all their actions are not apart from enlightenment.
Why is this?
In all dharmas there are obstructions of darkness. Destroying the obstructions of darkness is itself enlightenment. Therefore, bodhisattvas are always not apart from enlightenment.
If bodhisattvas think like this:
'I am apart from enlightenment.'
One should know that such a person will not attain enlightenment.
If one thinks:
'I now have enlightenment,' then such a person's enlightenment will be pure or impure.
If one is able to contemplate all dharmas in this way, one will attain enlightenment, which is the skillful means of pure wisdom.
Good man!

Innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas ago, there was a Buddha who appeared in the world, called AmitÄbha TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Person, Tamer, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One;
The land was called AbhinÄ«lanetra, and the kalpa was called PrabhÄsvÄn.

At that time, when the World-Honored One was first sitting in the place of enlightenment under the bodhi tree, before he had yet attained Buddhahood, the bodhisattvas who were one life away from Buddhahood and those who were irreversible from the stage of nonretrogression in the worlds of the ten directions all came to see him. After arriving there, they made offerings to him with various flowers, which floated in the air seven tÄla trees above.
After attaining Buddhahood, he emitted a great light that illuminated the ten directions. In the worlds of the ten directions, many devas, upon seeing the Buddha's light, each said:
The Buddha of Boundless Light has truly appeared in the world.

The adornments of that Buddha's world were as splendid as the palace of the Paranirmita-vaÅ›avartin Heaven. At the beginning of that kalpa, after ten thousand years had passed, a Buddha appeared in the world named Jyotirasa. Therefore, this kalpa is called Jyotirasa.
Good man!

In the Jyotirasa kalpa, there were 1.4 billion Buddhas who appeared in the world. That Buddha's world had 96,000 small countries. Each country was 84,000 yojanas long and wide. Each country had 84,000 cities, each city being one yojana long and wide. In each city, there were 84,000 people living.
That land was fully endowed with such things.

The land is purely adorned with the four treasures, namely gold, silver, lapis lazuli, and crystal. It is abundant in food and drink, with nothing lacking, and the people of that land have no sense of ownership, just like in the northern continent of Uttarakuru.
The lifespan of that Buddha is ten intermediate kalpas. The great assembly of Å›rÄvakas is 96,000 koá¹­is, and the great assembly of bodhisattvas is 12,000 koá¹­is.
There are two cities in that land:
The first is called Joy;
The second is called Purity.
The World-Honored Buddha was born in the city of Purity and resides in the city of Joy.
There is a king in that land named Pure Voice, who possesses the seven treasures and rules over the trichiliocosm.

He has 36,000 palace ladies, whose faces are upright and dignified, no different from the gods. He has 100,000 sons who are heroic and valiant, all possessing half the power of NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, each endowed with the thirty-two marks, and all of them have given rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
There were eighty thousand women, pure and undefiled, with extraordinary heavenly appearances, all of whom also gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.

For two eons, the king made offerings to the TathÄgata, the assembly of Å›rÄvakas and bodhisattvas. For the sake of the TathÄgata, he constructed a jeweled monastery extending for five yojanas. Within the jeweled monastery, there were again hundreds of thousands of jeweled towers, for the sake of making offerings to the saá¹…gha.
At that time, the holy king and his retinue all cultivated pure and chaste conduct.
At that time, the Buddha taught immeasurable beings the MahÄyÄna Dharma, and again taught innumerable [beings] the ÅšrÄvakayÄna.

At that time, after the king made offerings to the Buddha, he went to where the Buddha was together with his retinue. He bowed his head to the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him respectfully, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and said to the Buddha:
'World-Honored One!ğŸ”½How do bodhisattvas cultivate the MahÄyÄna and not follow the words of others?
How do bodhisattvas attain the ultimate?
How can bodhisattvas attain non-abiding?
How can bodhisattvas attain unwavering wisdom?
How can bodhisattvas attain pure wisdom?
How can bodhisattvas see far with their power?
How are bodhisattvas' faculties sharp?
How are bodhisattvas endowed with a buddha land?
How do bodhisattvas practice heedfulness?
How are bodhisattvas not afraid when hearing the profound Dharma?
How are bodhisattvas called bodhisattvas?
The Buddha said:
Great King!
There are four practices for cultivating the Great Vehicle without following the words of others.
What are the four?
First, being fully endowed with noble faith and going beyond the world;
second, being fully endowed with wisdom and contemplating the nature of phenomena;
third, being fully endowed with spiritual powers;
fourth, cultivating pure diligence in order to transform sentient beings.
Great King!
Bodhisattvas who are fully endowed with these four practices cultivate the Great Vehicle without following the words of others.
There are also four dharmas that lead to ultimate attainment.
What are the four?
First, knowing the good dharmas in order to subdue the mind;
Second, not being greedy for one's own happiness;
Third, cultivating compassion for all sentient beings;
Fourth, always delighting in the Mahayana;
These are called the four.
Great King!
There are also four dharmas that lead to non-abiding.
What are the four?
First, purifying the mind;
Second, pure adornments;
Third, being free from deception;
Fourth, cultivating firm wisdom to accumulate merit and virtue;
These are called the four dharmas.
Great King!
There are also four dharmas that lead to pure wisdom.
What are the four?
First, pure eyes;
Second, using the four means of attraction to gather in sentient beings;
Third, purifying the body's thirty-two marks and eighty minor characteristics;
Fourth, purifying the Buddha land and contemplating the pure Dharma realm;
These are called the four.
Great King!
There are also four dharmas that enable one to see far and have sharp faculties.
What are the four?
First, remembering the Bodhi tree without abandoning the bodhi mind;
Second, remembering the Buddha's wisdom without being attached to wisdom;
Third, remembering the Dharma body, cultivating emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness;
Fourth, remembering the Buddha's nirvana, without being weary or regretful in the cycle of birth and death;
These are called the four.
Great King!
There are also four dharmas that fully cultivate the Buddha land and practice non-negligence. What are the four?
First, taking on the body of Åšakra, transforming the devas and causing them to be non-negligent;
Second, taking on the body of BrahmÄ, transforming the devas and causing them to be non-negligent;
Third, taking on the body of a wheel-turning king, transforming beings and causing them to be non-negligent;
Fourth, taking on the body of a great minister or elder, fully endowed with precious treasures, transforming beings and causing them to be non-negligent;
These are called the four.
Great King!
There are also four dharmas by which one hears the profound Dharma without fear in one's mind.
What are the four?
First, being close to good friends;
Second, good friends expounding the profound Buddha Dharma for one;
Third, being able to contemplate well;
Fourth, abiding in accordance with the Dharma;
These are called the four.
Great King!
There are also four dharmas by which one attains the name of a bodhisattva.
What are the four?
First, seeking the perfections;
Second, cultivating compassion for sentient beings;
Third, delighting in seeking the Buddha Dharma;
Fourth, not being weary or regretful when transforming sentient beings;
These are called the four.
' Good man!

At that time, King Pure Sound, having heard this Dharma from that Tathagata, together with all his retinue, all attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, abandoned his country and kingdom, left home to cultivate the Way in the Buddha Dharma.
At that time, the World Honored One told the king:
'Great King!
Your present renunciation is already repaying the Buddha. If you can give rise to such faith and let go, this is called the great repayment, this is called merit, and it benefits many.
Great King!
There are twenty-four benefits to a bodhisattva's renunciation.
What are the twenty-four?
First, abandoning worldly affairs and attaining great freedom;
Second, abandoning afflictions and attaining liberation;
Third, wearing dyed robes and attaining the unstained path;
Fourth, perfecting the four things and attaining the four kinds of spiritual powers;
Fifth, delighting in ascetic practices and being far removed from all great desires and evil desires;
Sixth, not abandoning the aggregate of precepts and receiving the bliss of humans and gods;
Seventh, not abandoning bodhi and attaining the Buddha's teachings;
Eighth, always delighting in tranquility and being free from worldly talk;
Ninth, not being attached to the Dharma and attaining the great pure mind;
Tenth, being endowed with the branches of meditation, one attains meditative concentration;
Eleventh, seeking much learning, one attains wisdom;
Twelfth, destroying arrogance, one attains wisdom;
Thirteenth, eliminating wrong views, one attains right views.
Fourteenth, not giving rise to discursive thoughts, for the sake of truly understanding the Dharma realm;
Fifteenth, regarding all sentient beings equally, one attains great kindness;
Sixteenth, transforming sentient beings without wearying, one attains great compassion;
Seventeenth, not sparing one's body and life, for the sake of protecting the Dharma;
Eighteenth, calming one's mind, for the sake of attaining spiritual powers;
Nineteenth, recollecting the TathÄgata, for the sake of seeing the Buddha;
Twentieth, cultivating wholesome thoughts, for the sake of attaining the profound wisdom of the twelve links of dependent origination;
Twenty-first, attaining the acceptance of conformity;
Twenty-second, attaining the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas;
Twenty-third, to have faith in all merits;
Twenty-fourth, to attain the wisdom of the Buddha.
These are called the twenty-four.
' Good man!

At that time, when the sage king heard this Dharma, he turned and taught it to all the men, women, relatives, ministers, and people. At that time, in that country, 99.9 trillion beings all left home together.
Good man!
After the bhiká¹£u Pure Sound left home, he again addressed the Buddha, saying:
'World-Honored One!
How can I now be called one who has left home?'
The Buddha said:
'Bhiká¹£u!
You are named Pure Sound. You should purify your own realm. If your own realm is purified, then you are called a bhiká¹£u and you are called one who has left home.'
At that time, when the bhiká¹£u heard the Buddha's words, he delighted in tranquility and had this thought:

'The realm is the eye. One who observes the emptiness of the eye is the pure realm. The pure realm is precisely the Buddha land. The ear, nose, tongue, and body are also like this. The mind is the realm. If one observes the emptiness of the mind, it is the pure realm. The pure realm is precisely the Buddha land. It is precisely the one realm, which is precisely the empty realm, precisely the realm of sentient beings, precisely the realm of signlessness, precisely the realm of wishlessness, precisely the realm of non-action, precisely the realm of the unconditioned.'
Good man!

When the bhiká¹£u Pure Sound had such observations, he immediately attained lightness of body and lightness of mind. Having attained lightness of body and mind, he attained immeasurable spiritual powers. Having attained spiritual powers, he attained the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« door of unobstructed eloquence.
Good man!ğŸ”½Do you know that the bhiká¹£u Pure Sound of that time was none other than
you?
Your relatives, male and female, were precisely the assembly of bodhisattvas who came to listen to the Dharma that you brought.
When this Itipiá¹­aka was spoken, eighteen thousand people gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, and eight thousand beings attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.
Good sons!
If there are those who wish to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment, they should speak the Dharma as it is and abide as it is taught.
What is meant by speaking the Dharma as it is and abiding as it is taught?
Good sons!
If there are people who say:
'I will become a Buddha and invite all beings, promising them the taste of the Dharma,

but after inviting them, I am unable to uphold, recite, and expound this subtle sutra, I am unable to uphold the pure precepts, diligently cultivate and make progress, and cultivate contentment, having little contentment in the good Dharma. This is called deceiving and not speaking the Dharma as it is or abiding as it is taught.'
If there are people who say:
'I will become a Buddha and invite all beings, promising them the taste of the Dharma,

After requesting, they should uphold, recite, and expound it, protect and uphold the precepts, diligently cultivate and make energetic progress, have few desires and be content, and be able to obtain wholesome dharmas without giving rise to the thought of being satisfied. This is called not deceiving, speaking in accordance with the Dharma and abiding in accordance with the teaching.
Good sons!
It is like a king who invites many guests, but after inviting them, he does not prepare the necessary provisions for the guests. When the guests arrive, he says, 'I have not yet finished preparing.'
Then the guests each say:
'Yesterday we received the king's invitation, but our families did not prepare food. Now we are going to the king's place, but we will not get anything.'
They scold, worry, resent, lament, and weep.
Good sons!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas invite sentient beings and promise to give them the food of the Dharma, but do not seek to hear much, uphold the precepts, and make energetic progress. They do not cultivate the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment. Sentient beings scold them, and humans and gods weep.
Good sons!
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to act in accordance with what they should do and speak in accordance with what they do, they should not deceive any sentient beings.
Furthermore, good sons!
There are sentient beings who request the bodhisattva:
'Please expound the Dharma for me.'
The bodhisattva promises:
'I will expound it for you.'
Having promised, he becomes negligent.
When sentient beings see the bodhisattva being negligent, they then exhort and encourage him, and only then does he expound the Dharma.

When expounding, he may be asked about the profound meaning, but due to negligence, he is unable to answer. Because he is unable to answer, he feels ashamed and embarrassed, and in order to protect his body and mind and deceive sentient beings, he then abandons them.
Good sons!
If the bodhisattva wishes to abide as he speaks, he should have no regard for his body and mind in order to protect sentient beings.
Good sons!
In the past, there was a lion king who lived in a deep mountain cave, always thinking like this:
'I am the king of all beasts. With my power, I can protect all beasts.'
At that time, in that mountain, there were two monkeys who gave birth to two children.
At that time, the monkey said to the lion king,
If the king can protect all the animals, I will now entrust my two children to you, and I will go elsewhere to seek food and drink.
At that time, the lion king immediately agreed, and the monkey left his two children with the beast king and left.
At that time, in the mountains there was a vulture king named Sharp-sighted. While the lion king was sleeping, he immediately seized the monkey's two children and stayed in a dangerous place.
At that time, the king woke up and spoke a verse to the vulture king:
I now invite the great vulture king, please listen to my words with utmost sincerity,
Please release them for my sake, do not let me lose my faith and give rise to shame.
The vulture king spoke a verse in reply to the lion king:
I can fly and roam in the sky, having passed beyond your territory, I am fearless,
If you must protect these two children, you should abandon this body for my sake.'
The lion king said:
'I now abandon my body for the sake of protecting these two children, not sparing it like withered grass.
If I protect my body and speak falsely, how can I be called one who practices as they speak?'
Having spoken this verse, he immediately went to a high place, wishing to abandon his body.
At that time, the vulture king spoke another verse, saying:
'If one abandons one's body and life for the sake of others, that person will immediately receive unsurpassed joy.
I now give you these two monkeys. Great Dharma King, do not harm yourself.'
